—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. When the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 was amended in 1983, did sections 16 (1) and (2) correspond to sections 2 (1) and (2) in the Senate Elections (Queensland) Act 1982, an Act which resulted from a private senator's Bill I introduced in the Senate in 1981? Further, when the various sections of the Commonwealth Electoral Act were renumbered and section 16 became section 39, did an error occur in section 39 (2) in that section 7 of the Constitution was wrongly referred to as section 6? Does this error make section 39 (2) inoperative, or was it a typographical error which occurred after the Act was amended? If section 39 (2) is now inoperative, will an amendment be made to rectify this error? If the error was typographical, is section 39 (2) still fully operative, and will the error be corrected when the Act is next reprinted?

—I have a short note on the matters raised by Senator Colston. I am unable to say whether the Commonwealth Electoral Act amendments referred to did result from a private senator's Bill that he introduced into the Senate in 1981, but I believe that is the case. I would not be surprised if it were the case because Senator Colston has acted as a catalyst and, indeed, his private member's Bills have been a model for legislative initiatives in this area. However, in regard to the questions he asked, I am advised that an error was not made in the amending Act but that an error appeared in the 1984 reprint. The error occurred, I am told, in the publications section of the Australian Government Publishing Service. I am advised that this does not affect the Act, so the Act remains fully operative as originally amended. The error will be corrected in the next reprint. The timing of that will depend on the printing program. I believe that the Electoral Act is not high on the list, but the correction will be undertaken as soon as possible.

question.block.title: VIETNAM VETERANS: EFFECTS OF THE USE OF CHEMICALS

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. When does the Minister expect to receive Mr Hogg's report on the adequacies or otherwise of the final report of the Evatt Royal Commission on the Use and Effect of Chemical Agents on Australian Personnel in Vietnam? When the Minister receives Mr Hogg's report, to whom will it be made available and when?

—I have an answer to the honourable senator's question. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Humphreys, has received a report from Mr Bob Hogg. Mr Hogg's task as the consultant was to help the Minister for Veterans' Affairs in his preparation of proposals to go forward in a submission to Cabinet, taking into account work done by Government departments and submissions made by veterans' affairs associations. The question of the release of Mr Hogg's report will be taken up in the context of Cabinet's consideration of the Minister's submission.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Local Government. The Minister will be aware of the increasing participation by local government in the area of community services, extra to roads, rates and rubbish. Local government is not only helping to deliver such services but is more and more addressing the actual provision of community services. Can the Minister say what role the Federal Government is playing in this area, whether special funds are being allocated from the Federal level to this work or whether the Federal role is confined to the planning and rationalisation of resources?

answer.speaker: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

talk.start.para: —It is indeed true that local government has a very important role to play in the delivery of community services, and this role was recognised by the Prime Minister in his policy speech in July, when he gave a commitment for this Government to consider devolution of responsibilities undertaken at the Federal level back to local government authorities. It was his recognition of local government's crucial role in the delivery of community services that prompted that particular announcement. Over the next few months I expect to be talking in much more detail about those devolution proposals. Last Friday, I addressed the Community Services Association of Victoria and heard from it about a number of very exciting proposals that have been undertaken in that State, involving community service provision at the local government level. In my State and former city council of Townsville we were deeply involved in the provision of community services.

answer.para: The Commonwealth recognises the importance of local government's role in the planning and provision of services at the local government level. The Commonwealth continues to encourage and assist local government effectively to play its part in an efficient public sector capable of meeting community needs. For example, funds to local government for children's services are expected to grow by 27 per cent this year to $88m. Funding to local government under the home and community care program will be increased by 40 per cent in 1987-88, which is very significant in real terms. The home and community care program is one in which local government is particularly involved. In Victoria, local government has pioneered a great deal of work in the provision of Meals on Wheels services.

The Commonwealth will be developing a response to the Local Government Ministers conference task force report on community development, human services and local government. It recommended a more planned approach to the development of human services and the adoption of policies to guide the relationships between State and Federal agencies and local government. The Commonwealth has sponsored two conferences. Mr President, I am rather concerned, and I am sure that listeners will be, that the Opposition has so little interest in the development of community services at the local government level that Opposition members seem to prefer talk during the detailing of this very important information that I have for them.

The Commonwealth has sponsored two conferences which, for the first time, brought local government community services practitioners together on a national basis. These have been critical in assisting local government to develop its role in community services and its relationships with other levels of government. The local government development program will continue to be used to strengthen the capacity of local government to plan, co-ordinate and deliver community services consistent with the national objectives. Last year, community services projects were one of the priority areas for funding, with 29 projects receiving some $600,000. In 1987-88 community services projects will continue to receive top priority.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Further to Senator Peter Baume's earlier question about Fiji and the Minister's rather confused answer, I ask the Minister: Why are the Government's attitudes to Fiji and New Caledonia diametrically opposed? Is it not true that in New Caledonia the Hawke Government is supporting the indigenous minority and seeking to override the clearly expressed democratic wishes of the majority?

answer.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: —There is no parallel, again, between those two situations. The Government's position on New Caledonia is well known. It has been enunciated on numerous occasions by Mr Hayden and, to a lesser extent, by me in this place. In the first instance, it involves a desire that all the people of New Caledonia participate in an effective exercise in self-determination conducted in accordance with United Nations principles, not on the basis on which the present referendum was conducted, which referendum as a result was, understand- ably enough, boycotted by a very significant proportion of the New Caledonian people because no serious alternatives were put to the people involving, for example, the intermediate status of independence in association with France, an option which might well have satisfied a number of people's aspirations. There was no extended process of education about the various options and alternatives leading up to that referendum and the whole affair took place in the context of a most unhappy atmosphere as a result of the actions of the authorities concerned.

answer.para: We have indicated support in the past for the Fabius-Pisani plan, as it had been devised and developed by the French authorities earlier, and we continue to espouse a position, not one that is an argument for dominance by the now ethnic minority in that country but one that fully recognises the claims of those people to a serious, respected and dignified voice in the shaping of the future of their own country, not something that has been able to take place in the way in which that territory has been administered to date.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the recent rise in new dwelling approvals in the housing market and to the significant upward movement in the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd job advertisement series in August. Are these, in addition to the recent unemployment figures, further indications that the Government's economic strategy for the financial year 1987-88 is on track?

—The September Treasury bulletin confirms what Senator Maguire has said. It reports that the ANZ bank job advertisement series rose by 3.1 per cent in August, to be some 5 per cent higher than it was a year ago, and that the number of building approvals for new dwellings increased by 5.2 per cent in July and by 6.3 per cent for the three months to July. Statistics such as those do not please the Opposition because, apart from contradicting its own forecasts, the Opposition realises that they also further erode whatever limited chance it might have of getting into government one day. It is because of that that when something initiated overseas inevitably spills on to Australia, such as the recent decline in the stock market, it is greeted by the Opposition with ill-concealed delight and the probably forlorn hope that it will do some damage to the real economy as distinct from the casino activity which has been featured in stock markets over the last eight or nine months in particular.

—My question, which is to the Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health, refers to the serious effects which the Federal Government's Medicare arrangements are having on staffing levels in Queensland hospitals. Is it a fact that, under the Medicare agreement, Queensland receives $82.86 per capita whilst the average of the other States of Australia is $198.80? Is it a fact that the South Australian Government receives $257.46, which is more than three times the amount per capita than is received in Queensland? Is the Minister aware that, if the identified health grants are added to that, the total amount received by New South Wales from the Commonwealth is $1,039m whilst the Queensland figure is a mere $205m? Does the Minister not agree that these are serious discrepancies and is she in a position to explain why they have occurred?

—I am not in a position to confirm the figures which Senator Bjelke- Petersen cited in her question. Therefore, I cannot agree that there is an anomaly or a discrepancy. I very much doubt that there would be. I recall that the matter of negotiating Medicare agreements with the States was a very long and drawn out one and involved a long period of difficulty in Queensland, after which agreement was reached. So I very much doubt that there is any anomaly. Because I am not in a position to comment on the specific figures quoted in Senator Bjelke-Petersen's question, I will refer the matter to Dr Blewett and get a proper response.

—I draw the attention of the Minister for Transport and Communications to Press reports about the need for installation of radar and for increased staffing levels to deal with the growth in air traffic at Cairns. I ask: What actions are being taken by the Government to improve air traffic control at Cairns?

answer.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: —We are well aware of the greater than forecast growth in air traffic movements in north Queensland, especially affecting Cairns Airport. A central and regional office task force was established some seven months ago and identified many areas to assist air traffic control at Cairns in carrying out its functions. The task force made approximately 30 recommendations which are presently being actioned. The Government announced in June this year that radar will be installed in Cairns as part of a program to enhance radar coverage along the Queensland coast. Tenders for this major program will be let during 1988 and installation at Cairns is anticipated to be completed by the end of 1990. Due to the procurement lead times for equipment of this complexity, it is impossible to have the facility operational any earlier than that.

answer.para: Close examination is being given to ensure that the current staff and procedures are adequate to meet the increasing air traffic demands at Cairns. New staffing proposals are currently under consideration within the Department. A number of further talks are proceeding on these issues. I simply make the point that there is no justification for the precipitate action and some of the more extravagant claims that have been made by some of the industrial interests concerned. The situation is completely manageable. Action has been taken to deal with it and full radar coverage is on its way.

talk.start.para: —I address my question to the Minister for Transport and Communications. What is the Government's attitude to Mr Halfpenny's suggestion that there should be a Senate inquiry into dealings between the Government and Sir Peter Abeles, including any involvement in the coastwatch contract fiasco?
—The Government's attitude is one of comprehensive dismissal. It is a piece of totally unjustified grandstanding that bears no conceivable relationship to any public interest.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the fall in unemployment, as measured by the Australian Bureau of Statistics in September, to below 8 per cent. Does the Minister have any information as to the last occasion on which the Opposition asked a question in this place concerning the general level of unemployment in Australia? Were the recent unemployment fi-gures consistent with the Government's policies as laid down in the Budget?

—I have been asked whether I can remember when the Opposition last asked a question about the general level of unemployment. The answer is that I cannot remember, but I am pretty confident that it was a very long time ago. Indeed, I doubt whether the Opposition has asked any question about unemployment this year, but I suppose that that can be checked out. Until Senator Button's absence this week I had not had any responsibility for the Department of Industrial Relations since the last election. I guess that, from the Opposition's spectacular disinterest in unemployment levels, one could conclude--
—What about yesterday's question on Priority One? Why do you try to mislead the Senate?

—Was that a former stockbroker who said that? It could reflect the Opposition's disappointment that the employment figures have been very good and have more than met the expectations predicted in the last Budget and are on track to meeting the expectations in this Budget.

—I seek your guidance, Mr President. I have already advised Senator Walsh that, after Question Time, I propose to raise the total failure of the Department of Industrial Relations to answer questions put in this place. On 23 September, I put a question which is still not answered. On 8 October, I put a question which is still not answered.
—On a point of order, Mr President: Senator Chaney is trying to abuse Question Time by turning it into a debate.
—Order! Senator Chaney has the call and I am waiting to hear his point of order.
—I am seeking your guidance, Mr President. Is it open to the Minister to complain about a failure of the Opposition to ask questions in an area where the Government has refused to answer?
—Order! There is no point or order. I have no power as to how the Minister will answer the question.
—Before that completely spurious attempt to turn Question Time into a debate about whatever Senator Chaney feels like debating, I had finished my answer.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Is it a fact that the Government intends scaling down the defence contract offices in Brisbane, Adelaide and Perth in the near future? If so, how can this disruption to local contracting be justified when defence contracting restricted to Sydney, Melbourne and Canberra is more likely to increase costs than reduce them? Defence contracts in Brisbane were worth $30m last year and any scaling down would easily halve that amount.

answer.speaker: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has been examining a large number of measures to improve efficiencies in the defence portfolio. These measures include a major review of the defence logistics organisation and the contracts organisation. In the contracts area, the Government is looking to make savings of the order of $8m in the first year of operation. Action has been taken to change the existing contracting arrangements in Brisbane, Adelaide and Perth, as Senator Sheil's question indicates. Discussions are taking place with relevant unions, State governments and industry associations about the new arrangements. It is intended to maintain small contract administration offices in those areas. I am assured by the Minister for Defence that the new arrangements will lead to greater efficiency in the contracting area.

answer.para: It is not necessarily a fact that, because the number of contract offices is reduced, the number of contracts in those States will in any way be reduced. But I might just add that it is impossible, if a government is trying to slash $2 billion-odd off government expenditure, that there not be reductions in some areas. It is not much good for the Opposition to say that we are reducing expenditure in this or that area when its basic philosophical position is to double the amount of expenditure cuts, always unspecified, when it comes to Budget time. We have to make some savings in the defence area so that we can concentrate defence expenditure on those areas of priority that I am sure we have a bipartisan approach to.

talk.start.para: —Is the Minister for the Environment and the Arts aware of the phenomenon of electromagnetic pulse? Is he aware that a single nuclear explosion at a height above about 200 kilometres over the central United States of America would destroy all communications systems based on transistors; that is, all radio, television, telephone, electric power systems, electric car ignitions and, in short, essentially all communication? Is the Minister therefore persuaded that, fearing the inability to retaliate through loss of the ability to communicate with rocket launchers, both the United States and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics would be inclined to launch all available nuclear weapons once nuclear hostilities began? Finally, does the Minister therefore accept that any nuclear war is likely to escalate rapidly to total nuclear war?

—I am not quite certain of the relationship between the question and the Department of the Environment and the Arts. Nonetheless, one would imagine that a nuclear holocaust would have an effect on the environment, and in that respect, I suppose, some tender thread links the question and the person answering. Having said that, I must say that I am not an expert on pulse. We have a number of departments that could cover that point a little better than I. I could name three Australian Ministers as well as Messrs Reagan and Gorbachev who should all be consulted in getting an appropriate answer. My view is in accordance with the Government's view, as expressed many times in this chamber in the last couple of days. I do not think that I need to expand on it.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Justice. I again raise with the Minister Senator Crowley's serious allegations against a judge of the Family Court of Australia, suggesting that the judge should be dismissed because of a particular judgment. Yesterday, the Minister was unable to respond to my question about the Government's attitude to this serious matter which goes to the very heart of the administration of justice in this country. Has the Minister yet taken any action; and can he now inform the Senate of the Government's attitude?

answer.speaker: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

talk.start.para: —I did not understand, when Senator Crowley asked me her question on 20 October, that she was calling for the dismissal of the judge. In fact, I recall her asking whether the judgment provided grounds for dismissal, which is a slightly different matter. It was a more objective question. I have read the judgment delivered by the judge on 6 August 1987, as I undertook yesterday in the Senate to do. I took the opportunity last night to do so. Having read the judgment, one can see the sort of reasoning and the evidence before the judge which led to the sorts of conditions she attached to the foreshadowed award of custody to the mother. To that extent, whilst I am still of the view that the conditions deserve the description `extraordinary', there is a basis in the judgment for the conditions that were attached. But certainly it is the case that the decision is one that naturally has led to public concern.

answer.para: At the time I gave the answer in the Senate, no appeal process was under way. I understand that an appeal is to be lodged next week. That is the best way for any eccentricity that might be thought to be in the judgment to be sorted out-in the appeal process. I further understand that Justice Evatt, the Chief Judge of the Family Court-this has been reported to me; I have not heard the radio broadcast-fortuitously was being interviewed on the radio this morning on other matters. She indicated that the fact that an appeal process was to be got under way very shortly should lead to there being no further discussion on the topic. Certainly, it is not my intention to exacerbate the situation. As I said, I have read the judgment and I understand better the context which led to the conditions being attached to the decision on custody. May I also say that I have not had an opportunity to read any transcript or judgment that might have been put down in the return of the matter before the judge. I recall that that was after a two-month adjournment. Apparently the matter was back in court in early October. I have not had an opportunity to read any of those proceedings.

talk.start.para: —I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister answer the question that was put to him? What is the Government's attitude with respect to Senator Crowley's suggestion or inference that the judge ought to be removed as a consequence of this judgment? What steps has the Minister taken to clear that dark cloud over the judge's competence?

—I think I have indicated that I did not understand Senator Crowley to be asking for the dismissal of the judge. She was asking whether the judgment, in an objective sense, might provide grounds for removal. I and the Government have not taken any steps to deal with the judge; I think it would be quite improper to do so. The matter is best dealt with in the appeal process and that is the process which is now under way.
—We are talking about the judge's dismissal, not about the judgment.
—I do not believe that a judgment can provide a ground for dismissal; it is as simple as that. It ought to be dealt with by the appeal process which is under way.

—My question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, relates particularly to the wine industry. I ask the Minister: Can he indicate whether the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation has taken any initiatives recently to promote Australian wine internationally? Can he also indicate what the priority of such a campaign has been and the effects thereof?

answer.speaker: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

talk.start.para: —I do not have any specific information on the promotional activities of the Wine and Brandy Corporation, although I assume that that Corporation is promoting Australian wine sales on a continuing basis overseas. However, I am very well aware of the export performance of the wine industry over the last 12 months. That has been one of the spectacular successes, in proportional terms, of Australian exports. I have with me the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) bulletin dated 11 September 1987. I am not sure whether there is a more recent bulletin but this one reports on the sales of Australian wine and brandy for the month of July 1987. It states that the total volume of exports of Australian wine for the year ended June 1987 was over 21 million litres, more than a 95 per cent increase in the volume of Australian wine exports for the year ended June. Admittedly, that was from a reasonably low base, but to see exports almost double in 12 months is a matter of great satisfaction to the Government and, I would have thought, to everybody associated with the wine industry. While I am on the subject of that ABS bulletin of 11 September, let me say that it also draws attention to some major quirks in the recorded statistics in recent times. It states:

answer.para: . . . previously recorded total wine sales-
this is, total sales, not just exports-
for the year ended June 1987 have now been revised upwards to 330.0 million litres which now represents a 1.5 per cent increase over the year ended June 1986.

More significantly, the bulletin reports that the total wine sales for July 1987 were 33.2 million litres, an increase of more than 38 per cent from the June figure and an increase of more than 8 per cent on the figure for July 1986. It is rather extraordinary that the recorded sales for July this year were 38 per cent higher than they were for June and less remarkable, I suppose, they were 8.2 per cent higher than they were for July 1986.

This statistic has an acknowledged history of being somewhat unreliable and is based on the reported sales from major wineries which raises the question whether the major wineries have been as diligent in reporting their sales as they ought to have been. If one has a more suspicious mind, it raises the question whether there was deliberate under-reporting for the month of June. If it happened they probably acted in collusion with the Opposition in trying to mount a political campaign regarding the sales tax on the industry. Returning to the question of profit, it is a matter of great satisfaction to Government, and it ought to be a matter of great satisfaction to the wine industry, that the export performance of the last 12 months has been so spectacularly successful.

question.block.title: AUSTRALIAN PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO THE UNITED NATIONS GENERAL ASSEMBLY

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask you whether you would inform the Senate of the grounds you accepted, in conjunction with Madam Speaker, to refuse the funding of the Australian parliamentary delegation to the 1987 General Assembly of the United Nations in New York. Furthermore, have you taken any tangible measures to re-establish this funding?

—There is quite a large file on this matter. I believe that the Speaker and I wrote to the Prime Minister asking that the funding for that visit be reinstated. I will check the file to see what answer we received and I will report it to the Senate.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment and the Arts. As today is the final day for the receipt of submissions on the boundaries of north Queensland's wet tropical rainforests, can the Minister advise the Senate of the number and nature of submissions received and their implications for the Government's plans for this region?

answer.speaker: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

talk.start.para: —The number of submissions coming in is rising rapidly by the hour. I think last Friday it was about 1,500 and I am told that it is now almost 2,000 and it is still rising. I am very pleased to note that there is a submission from the Queensland Government. The Premier has put in a submission so there is the beginning of a faint hope of co-operation. Of course, the nature of the submissions varies widely from one-line rude suggestions to me to more in-depth submissions which ask for changes to the boundaries and argue the case for them.

answer.para: Last night I had a meeting with the Concerned Ladies Action Group (CLAG) from Ravenshoe; in fact, one of its members was a lady whose daughter had played the Last Post for me a couple of weeks ago. So impressed was I with CLAG that we resumed our discussions at breakfast this morning. That group has put in a submission encased in 1945 prime rainforest timber. Within that submission I think 100 individuals from Ravenshoe have written in with varying sorts of submissions. As far as the implications for the future are concerned, I hope that we will be in a position to finalise the boundary by the end of November. To that end a number of people are currently assessing those submissions. We have tried, as far as it is possible, to assess the submissions as they have been coming in. But given the huge rush in the last week, it will take some time. I am hopeful that by the end of November we will be in a position to announce a final boundary.

talk.start.para: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs concerned about the increasing level of delays in the processing of immigration applications? Can she confirm the fact that a person lodging a business migration application in Berne, Switzerland can expect an average processing time of 14 months before a visa is issued? Given the fact that the Government claims that it wants a sharper economic focus in its immigration program, does the Minister not find it appalling that such valuable immigrants to Australia have to wait such an inordinately long time for their visas to be issued?
—I am not aware of the case that Senator Knowles has raised but I will take the question on notice and ask the Minister to provide a response.

—Mr President, my question also is to you. I refer to a recent newspaper report describing the `sick building syndrome'-consequent on bacteria, viruses and other micro-organisms in air-conditioning and cooling systems. Can you say, Mr President, how often the Parliament House air-conditioning and cooling systems are examined and cleaned-if they are-particularly in the light of the number of sick people in Parliament House at the moment?

—I am not able at this time to give Senator Crowley that information. If she and Senator MacGibbon had raised the questions with me previously I would have been able to give much more comprehensive answers.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Transport and Communications been drawn to a report in today's Australian newspaper concerning the Government's ill-starred proposal to introduce an auctioning system for the issuing of new radio licences? Does the Minister maintain this high degree of expectation of getting Cabinet and Caucus approval of the auctioning proposal in light of the hostile reception it received from the transport and communications Caucus sub-committee at yesterday's meeting and also in the light of the almost unanimous opposition to the proposal from the radio broadcasting industry? Does the Minister agree that the auctioning proposal in its current form could unduly increase the concentration of radio ownership and effectively prevent small community-based groups from obtaining licences? If so, is the Minister considering any proposal to provide some degree of protection to local or community-based radio interest groups in obtaining FM licences?
—The honourable senator should know by now never to believe everything he reads in the newspapers. As to the rest of his question, all will be revealed in due course.

debate.sub1.title: Minister for Industrial Relations: Answers to Questions-Police Patrols: Belconnen-Sydney International Piano Competition

proctext.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.

speech.speaker: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

talk.start.para: —It is a little ironic that in Question Time Senator Walsh raised the failure of the Opposition to ask questions of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis), given the record of questioning in this place and the failure of the Minister for Industrial Relations to respond. I think it was in May of this year that Mr Willis suggested that the bans provisions in the industrial relations legislation are moribund. That word seems to have become part of the industrial relations dictionary. There is an appearance of the Minister being rather moribund himself with respect to responding to issues which are raised with him.

speech.para: I ask the Government to look at the record of this Minister and to seek some better performance. It would appear that Senator Button's office has unsuccessfully tried to pursue answers. I wish to direct the attention of the Senate to the nature of the questions the Minister has failed to answer. On 23 September, about a month ago, I raised with the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations the demand by the Building Workers Industrial Union for the flow on to the Parliament House construction site of the $20 a week severance pay agreement reached with employers. Just prior to my asking that question Mr Justice Ludeke condemned the severance pay deals which had been done and said that they could not be justified under the wage fixing principles and that any further attempt to extend the payment was unacceptable. I asked on that date what steps the Government would take to ensure that the $20 severance payment would not be paid on the new Parliament House site unless it was a determination of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

Not surprisingly, the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations in this place was not able to answer that question. Senator Button said that he would refer the question to the Minister and obtain an answer. Since that time I have made regular requests to Senator Button's office for an answer. As that has produced nothing, I have made regular requests of Mr Willis's office and again there has been no response. Yet this is a matter in which the Minister has been directly involved in correspondence and in other activities and it must be a comparatively simple matter for the Government's attitude to be disclosed to this place and for the Minister to advise us whether the Government will take any action on this matter.

The second issue that I raised was the industrial dispute on the North West Shelf. That question was raised on 8 October at the time when a lengthy industrial dispute had been settled apparently by an agreement being entered into involving agreement to pay additional wages apparently well outside the national wage principles of the Government and of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. In this matter again there was direct Commonwealth Government involvement with the State Commissioner being given authority to act as a Federal commissioner also. Senator Button undertook on 8 October to get an update on what had happened. At that stage he had a note from the Minister dated 6 October. Again, it has been impossible to get an answer from the Minister's office.

There are two possibilities in this matter. The first is that the Minister's office and his Department are simply incapable of getting an answer to a question where there is a clear Commonwealth involvement and a clear ability to provide an answer. It may be that there is just massive inefficiency within the Minister's Department which precludes these relatively straightforward requests from being answered. The other possibility, of course, is that in both cases the Government is simply embarrassed by the fact that the agreements entered into appear to be outside the wages guidelines which have the support of the Government and which are, of course, a matter of great contention at the moment, given that the national wage case has been postponed and there are very significant issues to be determined about what wages policies should be followed given the difficult and uncertain economic conditions we face.

I raise the matter at this stage because the failure of the Minister to respond is making it more difficult for the Opposition, and indeed for the community, to make appropriate judgments on these issues. I do not regard it as vaguely acceptable that we should have to wait for more than four weeks for an answer to a straightforward question on a matter which is within the Government's knowledge and apparent competence and I express my concern. I think it is clear that that concern is not shared by Government Ministers. Senator Walsh, to whom I gave notice of this matter, has left the chamber and is obviously treating it as one which he can ignore. The other Ministers who are here are obviously not interested in it.

I simply wish to make public my dissatisfaction and the dissatisfaction of the Opposition at this attitude to Question Time. It is totally inappropriate that Ministers should adopt this cavalier attitude. I seek a response from the Government as to what attitude it has to the reasonably speedy answering of questions in this place. Since Senator Richardson is unable to answer questions even on his own portfolio I doubt that he will be able to give me much assistance on this matter. Given the contempt with which this matter has been treated, Mr President, I draw your attention to the state of the House.
(Quorum formed)

speech.speaker: Reid Sen M.E.

talk.start.para: —I raise a matter which is of importance in my electorate, in particular the Belconnen area. It arises from a number of incidents of vandalism in the area of the Kippax shopping centre recently. It is not just in the shopping centre area; it is more widespread than that. The question really is: What police protection is there for the community in the area? It is certainly the impression of most people in that area that there are fewer police around than there have been in the past.

speech.para: I think it might be useful if the relevant Minister obtained the following information: how many police have been on duty in each shift in the area of the Belconnen police station, say, in the last three weeks; and how many cars have been used in each shift? When I say `on duty', I am not talking about the officers in the police station; I am talking about the number of police out in the area on patrol who are able to attend calls that are made by members of the public.

The fact is that a considerable amount of damage is being done and it is necessary that there be a greater degree of police protection to see that this is stopped. In the end the community pays for any damage that is done. As the Minister for the Environment and the Arts (Senator Richardson) would know, insurance claims add to the cost of this expensive item. Also, distress is caused to the people. But the question that needs to be answered is the extent to which police from the Belconnen police station are available to attend calls in the community in respect of incidents. The police need to be able to attend quickly enough to do something about those incidents and to apprehend the people who are causing the problems. As I said, many people in the Belconnen area have gained the impression that far fewer police are now on duty and out and about on patrol. I ask the Minister to bring the facts to the Senate so that we can assess whether the area is being adequately policed and looked after, whether there are fewer police in the area than there have been in the past and whether the present situation is reasonable.

speech.speaker: Bishop Sen B.K. .

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on a matter which is of some personal concern to me. The Sydney International Piano Competition of Australia is an important competition which is conducted every four years throughout Australia. This competition gives young pianists the opportunity to compete with each other in Australia for the benefit of young Australian audiences in particular, as well as a more general audience. The competition, which began in 1978, has already achieved a huge status internationally. It is now regarded among the top five competitions of the world, including the Tchaikovsky competition, the Leeds and other well-known competitions. I am greatly concerned about the ideological stance which the Music Board of the Australia Council seems to take in this endeavour.

speech.para: It is important to note that the Sydney International Piano Competition of Australia will take place in the bicentennial year of 1988, one year earlier than would be normal so that it can fit in with the importance of this occasion. As I said, the Music Board has an ideological stance that somehow competitions are bad for artists. Generally, the Government seems to be quite pleased to see grants made available for sporting competitions and other fields of endeavour. It seems to me that its extraordinary attitude is disadvantaging young musicians in this country who are anxious to participate. It is important to note that we conduct overseas auditions to ensure that the best Australian artists compete. Places are always made available for Australian competitors to compete with the world's best.

I raise this matter because I feel that the Music Board's attitude is really quite unacceptable. I do not know whether it is possible for competitors, because of their virtuosity in terms of fingering exercises on the piano keyboard, to get a grant under a sporting allocation. But it seems to me to be a wrong allocation of resources if competitions per se are not eligible simply because artists are made to compete against each other. As I said, this attitude has been evident over the life of the competition. We would be hopeful that, with the Bicentennial coming up, perhaps the Music Board might relent on this occasion.

In a previous competition we obtained a grant which was used to commission three Australian works. Those works formed a compulsory part of the repertoire which the competitors played. This not only gave composers an opportunity to write fresh works but also, more importantly, gave the opportunity for those works to be performed before audiences who have a genuine interest and care for the piano.

As I said, I raise this matter this morning because I think it is important. We have reached a standard of excellence in Australia through the efforts of private enterprise and private individuals who are involved with the competition. Indeed, we have enjoyed good State support in New South Wales. I think it is a matter of national importance that the national form of government should give recognition through the Music Board of the Australia Council. The organisers of the competition should not be forced, as they have been on other occasions, to find other means of funding. I think this is a legitimate cause to have raised during this adjournment debate.

speech.speaker: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

talker.name: Senator RICHARDSON
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and the Arts)

talk.start.para: —I will raise with the relevant Minister the concerns of Senator Chaney and Senator Reid. I understand that there is some feeling on one of the issues, and I will endeavour to sort that out. In regard to the matter raised by Senator Bishop, I think it is the case that we are talking about the Performing Arts Board, given that the Music Board has gone into the Performing Arts Board as a result of the reorganisation of the Australia Council. In fact, I have received a number of representations on that question from some, as they say, prominent Australians. Allowing for the fact that the Australia Council makes its own decisions and that we have arm's-length funding, I am, nonetheless, writing to the Australia Council to see what can be done to clarify the position on competitions.
